sub_title: Senior School Teacher at Wellington College International Shanghai
summary:
Passionate educator, organised and proven middle leader with experience in leading Science, Chemistry and Extended Project departments in a premium international school. Strong teaching, and professional learning skills. For example:

• 15th year of relevant UK and international teaching experience.
• 5 years of middle leadership experience at a high achieving international school.
• A proven track record of raising standards evidenced by improved academic achievement, and increased year on year Value Added (VA)  for department (Chemistry). This was based on CEM data, student/parent feedback, and strong university offers.  
• A passion for lifelong learning, a student-centred approach to education, one that is broad, balanced and holistic in nature. 
• Range of and breadth and depth of experiences in IGCSE / GCSE, A-Level, IB (HL and SL), Key Stage 3 and 2. 
• Managed large whole school projects such as the STEAM Project involving up to 200 students, 35 teaching staff, 7 core departments. 
• Collaborated directly with Dulwich College London with the Extended Projects, with emphasis on professional networking and developing cross-curricular connections. 
• Strong research professional with an "Applying Psychology in the Workplace" Professional Certification from the University of Cambridge as well as completing a Master of Arts in Education.

- Co-manages the effective leadership of a very large, diverse science department (27 in 2014-2015). 
- Active pastoral form tutor, implementing the PEEC (Positive Education Extended Curriculum). 
- Demonstrable ability to lead and manage several departments concurrently with the Dulwich Extended Projects, Chemistry and Science teams. 
- Proven track record of leading and managing whole school projects successfully such as STEAM and Extended Projects. From the inception to detailed planning to effective implementation and subsequent evaluation stages. 
- Led CAIE Pilot Course (Cambridge Research Qualification), where students' attainment was exceptional. 14 out of 17 students achieved Distinctions / Merits despite early entry and their EAL context.
